questions.text: Wall most often fractured in a blowout fracture of orbit due to fist (Blowout) injury:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inferior Blow out fracture It results from trauma to orbit by objects like tennis balls, cricket balls, and human fists, leading to fracture of the floor and the medial wall of the orbit. It is usually caused by a sudden increase in orbital pressure due to an object where the object diameter is greater than the diameter of the orbital aperture. Blowout fracture usually involves the floor of the It is of further two types - Pure blowout fracture does not involve orbital rim, only floor fracture. Impure blowout fracture involves the orbital rim and/or adjacent facial bones.

Highyeild:

Signs Periocular ecchymosis, edema, etc. Infraorbital nerve anesthesia Double diploma occurs due to mechanical entrapment of the inferior rectus and oblique muscle. Enophthalmos - sunken eyeball X-ray ( water a view) - teardrop/hanging drop sign is seen in the antrum

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Superior - inferior is the correct option. Option: C. Medial - inferior is the correct option. Option: D. Lateral - inferior is the correct option.

Extraedge:

Rx- Avoid nose blowing Systemic antibodies Analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs Cold compresses Surgical repair is to be done within 10 -14 days of injury

questions.text: A 21-year-old boy presents with diplopia and restriction of eye movements following blunt trauma to his eye with a cricket ball while playing cricket at college. X-ray reveals teardrop opacity in the maxillary sinus. Which part of the orbit is most likely damaged?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inferior wall Inferior wall/floor of the orbit. Blow out fracture It results from trauma to orbit by objects like tennis balls, cricket balls, and human fists, leading to fracture of the floor and the medial wall of the It is usually caused by a sudden increase in orbital pressure due to an object where the object diameter is greater than the diameter of the orbital aperture. Blowout fracture usually involves the floor of the orbit/ inferior wall. It is of further two types - Pure blowout fracture does not involve orbital rim, only floor fracture Impure blowout fracture involves the orbital rim and/or adjacent facial bones

Highyeild:

Signs Periocular ecchymosis, edema, etc. Infraorbital nerve anesthesia Double diploma occurs due to mechanical entrapment of the inferior rectus and oblique muscle. Enophthalmos - sunken eyeball X-ray ( water a view) - teardrop/hanging drop sign is seen in the antrum

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Superior - inferior is the correct option. Option: C. Medial - inferior is the correct option. Option: D. Lateral - inferior is the correct option.

Extraedge:

Rx- Avoid nose blowing Systemic antibodies Analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs Cold compresses Surgical repair is to be done within 10 -14 days of injury

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room 30 minutes after being hit in the face with a baseball at high velocity. Examination shows left periorbital swelling, posterior displacement of the left globe, and tenderness to palpation over the left infraorbital rim. There is a limited left upward gaze and normal horizontal eye movement. Further evaluation will likely show what resulted from this patient's trauma?
questions.correct_answer: C. Clouding of the maxillary sinus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Clouding of the maxillary sinus The patient's findings of enophthalmos (posteriorly displaced eye) and infraorbital rim tenderness suggest an orbital floor fracture (orbital blowout fracture) . The mechanism of this injury can lead to downward displacement of orbital fat and inferior rectus muscle entrapment, which in turn can cause impaired upward gaze

Highyeild:

Maxillary Sinus Mucocele as a Late Complication in Zygomatic-Orbital Complex Fracture .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A .Injuring the lacrimal duct system is associated with nasoethmoidal Fracture of the maxillary bone in this portion of the medial orbital rim can also disrupt the medial canthal ligament, causing eyelid displacement and entrapment of the medial rectus muscle, which would prevent horizontal eye movement. Nasoethmoidal fractures are the second most common orbital fractures after orbital floor fractures. Still, this patient has no accompanying signs, and such a fracture would not explain his limited upward gaze or inferior orbital rim tenderness. Option: B . Pneumatization of the frontal sinus is a part of normal development as bone marrow in the frontal sinuses is slowly replaced by air from 2 years of age until adolescence. Pneumatization of the frontal sinuses may also occur due to orbital trauma in orbital roof fractures. These fractures are rare in adults because of the strength of the orbital roof. They are more common in children with a higher cranium-to-midface ratio than in Orbital roof fractures result in CSF leaks and mucocele formation , none of which are present in this patient. Option: D. Cerebrospinal fluid leak is seldom associated with orbital fractures. When a CSF leak does occur, it is typically due to an orbital roof fracture with an extension to the frontal sinuses. Orbital roof fracture is inconsistent with this patient's inferior orbital rim tenderness and limitation of upward gaze (signifying inferior rectus muscle entrapment).

Extraedge:

Clouding of the maxillary sinus is a radiological sign known as the "teardrop sign." It will likely be seen on further evaluation due to the inferior rectus muscle and orbital fat herniating through the fractured orbital floor.
